_link.title: I can predict whether a spontaneous redox reaction will occur between given species

toLevel2.question: When does a spontaneous redox reaction occur according to the electrochemical series?
toLevel2.correct: When the oxidising agent is higher on the left and the reducing agent is lower on the right
toLevel2.correctExplanation: A spontaneous reaction requires the oxidising agent (left side, higher E°) to react with the reducing agent (right side, lower E°). This is the 'top-left reacts with bottom-right' rule.

distractors.answer: When the oxidising agent is lower on the left and the reducing agent is higher on the right
distractors.explanation: This describes the reverse (non-spontaneous) arrangement. The oxidising agent must be higher, not lower.

distractors.answer: When both species are on the left side of the electrochemical series half-equations
distractors.explanation: If both are on the left, they are both oxidising agents and will not react with each other.

distractors.answer: When both species are on the right side of the electrochemical series half-equations
distractors.explanation: If both are on the right, they are both reducing agents and will not react with each other.

toLevel2.question: Will Pb²⁺(aq) spontaneously react with Cd(s)?
toLevel2.correct: Yes, because Pb²⁺ is higher on the left and Cd is lower on the right of the ECS
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Pb²⁺ (E° = −0.13 V, left side) is higher than Cd²⁺/Cd (E° = −0.40 V). Cd (right side, lower) is the reducing agent. Top-left reacts with bottom-right = spontaneous.

distractors.answer: No, because both species have negative E° values
distractors.explanation: Negative E° values do not prevent reactions. What matters is the relative position: Pb²⁺ is higher than Cd²⁺/Cd.

distractors.answer: No, because Pb²⁺ and Cd are both metals and metals do not react with each other
distractors.explanation: Pb²⁺ is an ion (not a metal), and metals can react with metal ions if the ECS positions are correct.

distractors.answer: Yes, because both species have negative E° values, which always means a reaction occurs
distractors.explanation: The sign of E° alone does not determine spontaneity. It is the relative position on the ECS that matters.

toLevel2.question: Will Ni²⁺(aq) spontaneously react with Pb(s)?
toLevel2.correct: No, because Ni²⁺ is lower on the left than Pb²⁺, so the positions are reversed
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Ni²⁺ (E° = −0.25 V) is lower than Pb²⁺ (E° = −0.13 V). For a spontaneous reaction, the oxidising agent must be higher on the left. The positions are reversed here.

distractors.answer: Yes, because Ni²⁺ can accept electrons from Pb to form Ni metal
distractors.explanation: Although Ni²⁺ can theoretically accept electrons, Pb (E° = −0.13 V) is above Ni (E° = −0.25 V) so Ni²⁺ cannot spontaneously oxidise Pb.

distractors.answer: Yes, because all metal ions react spontaneously with all metals
distractors.explanation: Not all metal ions react with all metals. The ECS determines which combinations are spontaneous.

distractors.answer: No, because Ni²⁺ and Pb are both in the same group of the periodic table
distractors.explanation: Periodic table groups do not determine redox spontaneity. The ECS positions are what matter.

toLevel2.question: Why will Pb²⁺(aq) and Cd²⁺(aq) not react spontaneously with each other?
toLevel2.correct: Because both species are on the left side of the ECS, so neither can act as a reducing agent
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Pb²⁺ and Cd²⁺ are both on the left side (oxidised forms). A reaction requires one species from the left (oxidising agent) and one from the right (reducing agent).

distractors.answer: Because they have identical E° values and cancel each other out completely
distractors.explanation: They have different E° values (−0.13 V and −0.40 V). The issue is that both are on the same side (left).

distractors.answer: Because both are positively charged ions and like charges always repel each other
distractors.explanation: Charge repulsion is not the reason. The issue is that both are oxidising agents with no reducing agent present.

distractors.answer: Because both species are already in their reduced forms and cannot be reduced further
distractors.explanation: Pb²⁺ and Cd²⁺ are oxidised forms (left side). They are not in their reduced forms. The issue is they are both on the same side.

toLevel2.question: A positive E°cell value indicates that a redox reaction is:
toLevel2.correctExplanation: When E°cell = E°cathode − E°anode is positive, the reaction proceeds spontaneously in the forward direction under standard conditions.

distractors.answer: Non-spontaneous under standard conditions
distractors.explanation: A negative E°cell indicates non-spontaneity. A positive E°cell means the reaction is spontaneous.

distractors.answer: At equilibrium and will not proceed in either direction
distractors.explanation: Equilibrium corresponds to E°cell = 0, not a positive value.

distractors.answer: Impossible regardless of any conditions applied
distractors.explanation: A positive E°cell means the reaction is spontaneous. Non-spontaneous reactions can also be forced with external energy.

toLevel2.question: A spontaneous redox reaction occurs when the oxidising agent is higher on the left side of the ECS than the reducing agent on the right side.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: This is the fundamental rule for predicting spontaneity: top-left species (strong oxidising agent) reacts with bottom-right species (strong reducing agent).

distractors.answer: False
distractors.explanation: Students may reverse the rule. The oxidising agent must be higher (more positive E°) on the left to spontaneously oxidise a species lower on the right.

toLevel2.question: Two species that are both on the right side of the electrochemical series will spontaneously react with each other.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Species on the right side are all reducing agents (reduced forms). A spontaneous reaction requires one from the left (oxidising agent) and one from the right (reducing agent).

distractors.answer: True
distractors.explanation: Two reducing agents cannot react with each other because neither can accept electrons. One species from each side is needed.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the rule for predicting spontaneous reactions.
toLevel2.sentence: A spontaneous reaction occurs when the {{blank:1}} agent is higher on the left and the {{blank:2}} agent is lower on the right of the ECS.

1.correctExplanation: The oxidising agent (species that accepts electrons) must be on the left side and higher in the ECS (more positive E°).

distractors.answer: reducing
distractors.explanation: The reducing agent is on the right side (lower). The left-side species is the oxidising agent.

distractors.answer: catalytic
distractors.explanation: Catalysts are not part of the ECS prediction. The left side contains oxidising agents.

2.correctExplanation: The reducing agent (species that donates electrons) must be on the right side and lower in the ECS (more negative E°).

distractors.answer: oxidising
distractors.explanation: The oxidising agent is on the left side (higher). The right-side species is the reducing agent.

distractors.answer: neutral
distractors.explanation: Neutral is not a redox term. The right side of ECS half-equations contains reducing agents.

toLevel2.prompt: Predict whether Cu²⁺(aq) reacts with Zn(s).
toLevel2.sentence: Cu²⁺ is {{blank:1}} on the left of the ECS than Zn²⁺, and Zn is on the right, so this reaction is {{blank:2}}.

1.correctExplanation: Cu²⁺ (E° = +0.34 V) is higher on the ECS than Zn²⁺ (E° = −0.76 V), making Cu²⁺ a stronger oxidising agent.

distractors.answer: lower
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ has a more positive E° (+0.34 V) than Zn²⁺ (−0.76 V), so it is higher, not lower.

distractors.answer: equal
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ (+0.34 V) and Zn²⁺ (−0.76 V) have very different E° values. They are not equal.

2.correctExplanation: Cu²⁺ (higher left) reacting with Zn (lower right) satisfies the rule for a spontaneous reaction.

distractors.answer: non-spontaneous
distractors.explanation: The positions satisfy the spontaneity rule: oxidising agent higher on left, reducing agent lower on right.

distractors.answer: impossible
distractors.explanation: The reaction is not only possible but spontaneous. Cu²⁺ + Zn → Cu + Zn²⁺ readily occurs.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the statement about E°cell and spontaneity.
toLevel2.sentence: If E°cell is {{blank:1}}, the reaction is spontaneous. If E°cell is {{blank:2}}, the reaction is non-spontaneous.

1.correctExplanation: A positive E°cell indicates the reaction has a thermodynamic driving force and will proceed spontaneously under standard conditions.

distractors.answer: negative
distractors.explanation: A negative E°cell means the reaction is non-spontaneous under standard conditions.

distractors.answer: zero
distractors.explanation: An E°cell of zero means the system is at equilibrium and no net reaction occurs.

2.correctExplanation: A negative E°cell means the reverse reaction is favoured. The forward reaction will not proceed spontaneously.

distractors.answer: positive
distractors.explanation: A positive E°cell means the reaction is spontaneous, not non-spontaneous.

distractors.answer: zero
distractors.explanation: Zero E°cell indicates equilibrium, not non-spontaneity. A negative value indicates non-spontaneity.

toLevel3.question: Using the ECS, will Ag⁺(aq) spontaneously react with Fe(s)? Explain your reasoning.
toLevel3.correct: Yes, because Ag⁺ (E° = +0.80 V) is higher on the left than Fe²⁺/Fe (E° = −0.44 V) on the right
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Ag⁺ is a stronger oxidising agent (higher left) and Fe is a stronger reducing agent (lower right). This satisfies the spontaneity rule.

distractors.answer: No, because Fe has a negative E° and Ag⁺ has a positive E°, so they cannot react
distractors.explanation: The sign difference actually supports spontaneity — the large positive E° difference means a strong driving force.

distractors.answer: Yes, but only because both species are metals, and all metals react with all metal ions
distractors.explanation: Not all metals react with all metal ions. Spontaneity depends on ECS positions, not just being metals.

distractors.answer: No, because Fe is higher on the ECS than Ag, preventing any reaction from occurring
distractors.explanation: Fe²⁺/Fe (E° = −0.44 V) is lower on the ECS than Ag⁺/Ag (E° = +0.80 V), not higher.

toLevel3.question: Why does the 'top-left reacts with bottom-right' rule work for predicting spontaneous reactions?
toLevel3.correct: Because the strongest oxidising agent (top left) has the greatest tendency to accept electrons from the strongest reducing agent (bottom right)
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Higher E° means greater tendency to be reduced (accept electrons). Lower E° means greater tendency to be oxidised (donate electrons). This complementary tendency drives the spontaneous reaction.

distractors.answer: Because elements at the top of the series are always more reactive than those at the bottom
distractors.explanation: Reactivity depends on the role (oxidising vs reducing). The top-left species are strong oxidising agents; bottom-right are strong reducing agents.

distractors.answer: Because the series is arranged alphabetically and reactions follow alphabetical order
distractors.explanation: The ECS is arranged by E° values, not alphabetically. The order reflects thermodynamic tendency.

distractors.answer: Because top-left species are lighter atoms that move faster and react before heavier bottom-right atoms
distractors.explanation: Atomic mass and speed are irrelevant. The rule is based on relative electrode potentials and electron transfer tendencies.

toLevel3.question: A student mixes Cu²⁺(aq) with Ag(s). Will a spontaneous reaction occur?
toLevel3.correct: No, because Cu²⁺ (E° = +0.34 V) is lower on the left than Ag⁺ (E° = +0.80 V)
toLevel3.correctExplanation: For Cu²⁺ to oxidise Ag, Cu²⁺ must be higher than Ag⁺ on the left side. Since Cu²⁺ is lower, it cannot spontaneously oxidise Ag. The positions are reversed.

distractors.answer: Yes, because Cu²⁺ is a strong oxidising agent that reacts with all metals
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ is a moderate oxidising agent. It cannot oxidise metals above it on the ECS, such as silver.

distractors.answer: Yes, because copper and silver are both transition metals that readily react together
distractors.explanation: Being transition metals does not guarantee a reaction. The ECS positions determine spontaneity.

distractors.answer: No, because Cu²⁺ and Ag are both on the right side of the ECS half-equations
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ is on the left side (oxidised form) and Ag is on the right side (reduced form). The issue is their relative positions.

toLevel3.question: If E°cell for a proposed reaction is calculated as −0.37 V, what does this tell you?
toLevel3.correct: The reaction is non-spontaneous; the reverse reaction is spontaneous instead
toLevel3.correctExplanation: A negative E°cell means the forward reaction is not thermodynamically favoured. The reverse reaction (with E°cell = +0.37 V) would be spontaneous.

distractors.answer: The reaction is spontaneous and will produce 0.37 V of electricity
distractors.explanation: A negative E°cell indicates non-spontaneity. Only positive E°cell values indicate spontaneous reactions.

distractors.answer: The reaction is at equilibrium and no net change will occur in either direction
distractors.explanation: Equilibrium corresponds to E°cell = 0 V. A negative value means the reverse reaction is favoured.

distractors.answer: The calculation must be wrong because E°cell values cannot be negative numbers
distractors.explanation: E°cell can be negative, indicating the reaction as written is non-spontaneous.

toLevel3.question: Zinc metal is placed into a solution containing Ag⁺ ions. Predict the outcome.
toLevel3.correct: A spontaneous reaction occurs: Zn is oxidised and Ag⁺ is reduced
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Ag⁺ (E° = +0.80 V, higher left) will oxidise Zn (E° = −0.76 V, lower right). E°cell = +0.80 − (−0.76) = +1.56 V, which is positive.

distractors.answer: No reaction occurs because zinc cannot reduce silver ions in solution
distractors.explanation: Zn is a strong reducing agent (low E°) that readily reduces Ag⁺ (high E°). The reaction is spontaneous.

distractors.answer: A spontaneous reaction occurs: Ag is oxidised and Zn²⁺ is reduced
distractors.explanation: The direction is reversed. Zn (lower E°) is oxidised, and Ag⁺ (higher E°) is reduced.

distractors.answer: No reaction occurs because Zn²⁺ and Ag⁺ are both on the left side of the ECS
distractors.explanation: The reactants are Ag⁺ (left) and Zn (right), not both on the same side. This is a valid spontaneous pair.

toLevel3.question: A student claims that Mg(s) can spontaneously reduce Cu²⁺(aq). Is this claim correct?
toLevel3.correct: No; Mg is the reducing agent that is oxidised, causing Cu²⁺ to be reduced — Mg does not 'reduce' Cu²⁺, it causes Cu²⁺ to be reduced
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The terminology is important: Mg is oxidised (loses electrons) and is the reducing agent. Cu²⁺ is reduced (gains electrons). Mg causes the reduction of Cu²⁺ by donating electrons.

distractors.answer: Yes; Mg reduces Cu²⁺ because Mg gains electrons from the copper ions
distractors.explanation: Mg loses electrons (is oxidised), it does not gain them. Cu²⁺ gains the electrons from Mg.

distractors.answer: No; Mg cannot react with Cu²⁺ because they are on opposite sides of the ECS
distractors.explanation: Being on opposite sides is exactly what allows the reaction. The reaction is spontaneous (Mg lower right, Cu²⁺ higher left).

distractors.answer: No; Mg is too reactive to participate in controlled redox reactions with Cu²⁺
distractors.explanation: Mg's high reactivity (low E°) actually makes it an excellent reducing agent for Cu²⁺ (higher E°).

toLevel3.question: If E°cell = 0 V for a proposed reaction, the system is at equilibrium and no net reaction occurs.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: An E°cell of zero means there is no thermodynamic driving force in either direction. The system is at equilibrium with no net reaction.

distractors.answer: False
distractors.explanation: Students may think zero means a very small reaction occurs. In fact, zero E°cell means equilibrium — no net reaction in either direction.

toLevel3.prompt: Apply the prediction rule to Fe²⁺(aq) and Zn(s).
toLevel3.sentence: Fe²⁺ (E° = −0.44 V) is {{blank:1}} on the left than Zn²⁺ (E° = −0.76 V), and Zn is on the right, so the reaction is {{blank:2}}.

1.correctExplanation: Fe²⁺ (E° = −0.44 V) has a more positive E° than Zn²⁺ (E° = −0.76 V), placing it higher on the ECS.

distractors.answer: lower
distractors.explanation: −0.44 V is more positive than −0.76 V, so Fe²⁺ is higher, not lower, on the ECS.

distractors.answer: equal
distractors.explanation: −0.44 V and −0.76 V are different values. Fe²⁺ is higher on the series.

2.correctExplanation: Fe²⁺ (higher left) + Zn (lower right) satisfies the spontaneity rule. E°cell = −0.44 − (−0.76) = +0.32 V (positive).

distractors.answer: non-spontaneous
distractors.explanation: The positions are correct for spontaneity: oxidising agent higher left, reducing agent lower right.

distractors.answer: impossible
distractors.explanation: The reaction is spontaneous. Fe²⁺ will oxidise Zn under standard conditions.

toLevel3.prompt: Explain why Cu(s) and Zn(s) do not react spontaneously.
toLevel3.sentence: Cu and Zn are both on the {{blank:1}} side of the ECS. A reaction requires one species from each side, so {{blank:2}} reaction occurs.

1.correctExplanation: Cu and Zn are both metals (reduced forms), which appear on the right side of ECS half-equations.

distractors.answer: left
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ and Zn²⁺ are on the left (oxidised forms). Cu(s) and Zn(s) are on the right (reduced forms).

distractors.answer: top
distractors.explanation: Top/bottom refers to position in the series. Left/right refers to which side of the half-equation the species appears on.

2.correctExplanation: Two species on the same side cannot react because they are both reducing agents (right) or both oxidising agents (left). One from each side is needed.

distractors.answer: a spontaneous
distractors.explanation: Two reducing agents (right side) cannot react with each other. No spontaneous reaction occurs.

distractors.answer: a vigorous
distractors.explanation: No reaction occurs at all. Species on the same side cannot undergo redox with each other.

toLevel3.prompt: Predict the reaction between Cl₂(aq) and I⁻(aq).
toLevel3.sentence: Cl₂ (E° = +1.36 V) is on the {{blank:1}} and higher than I₂/I⁻ (E° = +0.54 V). I⁻ is on the right and lower. Therefore, Cl₂ will {{blank:2}} I⁻ spontaneously.

1.correctExplanation: Cl₂ is the oxidised form in the Cl₂/Cl⁻ half-equation, appearing on the left side.

distractors.answer: right
distractors.explanation: Cl⁻ is on the right (reduced form). Cl₂ is on the left (oxidised form).

distractors.answer: bottom
distractors.explanation: Cl₂/Cl⁻ (E° = +1.36 V) is near the top of the ECS, not the bottom. Left/right indicates which side of the half-equation.

2.correctExplanation: Cl₂ (stronger oxidising agent, higher left) will accept electrons from I⁻ (lower right), oxidising I⁻ to I₂.

distractors.answer: reduce
distractors.explanation: Cl₂ is the oxidising agent — it oxidises I⁻, not reduces it. Cl₂ itself is reduced.

distractors.answer: neutralise
distractors.explanation: Neutralisation is an acid-base process. This is a redox reaction where Cl₂ oxidises I⁻.

toLevel4.question: Will a spontaneous reaction occur if copper metal is placed into Fe²⁺(aq) solution? Use E° values to justify.
toLevel4.correct: No; Cu²⁺/Cu (E° = +0.34 V) is higher than Fe²⁺/Fe (E° = −0.44 V), so Fe²⁺ cannot oxidise Cu
toLevel4.correctExplanation: For Fe²⁺ to oxidise Cu, Fe²⁺ must be higher on the left than Cu. But Fe²⁺ (E° = −0.44 V) is lower than Cu²⁺ (E° = +0.34 V). The positions are wrong for spontaneity.

distractors.answer: Yes; Cu is above Fe in the ECS so Cu will spontaneously dissolve in Fe²⁺ solution
distractors.explanation: Cu being above Fe means Cu²⁺ is a stronger oxidising agent, not that Cu will dissolve. Fe²⁺ cannot oxidise Cu.

distractors.answer: Yes; E°cell = +0.34 − (−0.44) = +0.78 V, which is positive and therefore spontaneous
distractors.explanation: This calculation assigns Cu as cathode, which is correct if Cu²⁺ is reduced. But Cu is the reactant metal, meaning it would need to be oxidised, giving a negative E°cell.

distractors.answer: No; but only because copper has a protective oxide layer like aluminium does
distractors.explanation: The reason is thermodynamic (ECS positions), not kinetic (oxide layer). Fe²⁺ is simply too low on the ECS to oxidise Cu.

toLevel4.question: Predict whether Br₂(aq) will spontaneously oxidise Fe²⁺(aq) to Fe³⁺(aq).
toLevel4.correct: Yes; Br₂/Br⁻ (E° = +1.09 V) is higher than Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺ (E° = +0.77 V), so Br₂ can oxidise Fe²⁺
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Br₂ (higher left, +1.09 V) will accept electrons from Fe²⁺ (lower right as part of the Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺ couple, +0.77 V). E°cell = +1.09 − 0.77 = +0.32 V (positive).

distractors.answer: No; both E° values are positive, so no reaction occurs between positive-E° species
distractors.explanation: Two positive E° values can still react. The higher one (Br₂) oxidises the lower one (Fe²⁺).

distractors.answer: No; Br₂ is a non-metal and cannot participate in redox reactions with metal ions
distractors.explanation: Non-metals can participate in redox. Br₂ is a strong oxidising agent that readily oxidises Fe²⁺.

distractors.answer: Yes; but Fe²⁺ is reduced to Fe(s), not oxidised to Fe³⁺ in this reaction
distractors.explanation: Br₂ oxidises Fe²⁺ to Fe³⁺ (removing an electron). Fe²⁺ is not reduced in this reaction.

toLevel4.question: A student wants to test if Sn²⁺(aq) will react with Ni(s). Calculate E°cell and predict the outcome.
toLevel4.correct: E°cell = −0.14 − (−0.25) = +0.11 V; spontaneous — Sn²⁺ oxidises Ni
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Sn²⁺/Sn (E° = −0.14 V) is higher than Ni²⁺/Ni (E° = −0.25 V). E°cell = −0.14 − (−0.25) = +0.11 V (positive), so the reaction is spontaneous.

distractors.answer: E°cell = −0.25 − (−0.14) = −0.11 V; non-spontaneous — no reaction occurs
distractors.explanation: The cathode is Sn²⁺ (higher E°) and the anode is Ni (lower E°). E°cell = −0.14 − (−0.25) = +0.11 V.

distractors.answer: E°cell = −0.14 + (−0.25) = −0.39 V; non-spontaneous — no reaction occurs
distractors.explanation: E°cell is calculated by subtraction (cathode − anode), not addition.

distractors.answer: E°cell = −0.25 + (−0.14) = −0.39 V; non-spontaneous — no reaction occurs
distractors.explanation: E°cell = E°cathode − E°anode = −0.14 − (−0.25) = +0.11 V. Do not add the values.

toLevel4.question: Predict whether I₂(s) can spontaneously oxidise Ag(s) to Ag⁺(aq).
toLevel4.correct: No; I₂/I⁻ (E° = +0.54 V) is lower than Ag⁺/Ag (E° = +0.80 V), so I₂ cannot oxidise Ag
toLevel4.correctExplanation: I₂ (E° = +0.54 V) is lower on the ECS than Ag⁺ (E° = +0.80 V). For spontaneity, the oxidising agent must be higher. I₂ is not a strong enough oxidising agent.

distractors.answer: Yes; I₂ is a halogen and halogens are strong oxidising agents that react with all metals
distractors.explanation: Not all halogens can oxidise all metals. I₂ (+0.54 V) is below Ag⁺ (+0.80 V), so it cannot oxidise Ag.

distractors.answer: Yes; E°cell = +0.80 − (+0.54) = +0.26 V, which is positive and spontaneous
distractors.explanation: This calculation assumes Ag⁺ is reduced (cathode), but Ag is the reactant. The correct calculation reverses roles: E°cell = +0.54 − 0.80 = −0.26 V (negative).

distractors.answer: No; but this is because silver is an inert metal that does not participate in redox reactions
distractors.explanation: Silver does participate in redox. The reason is thermodynamic: I₂ has a lower E° than Ag⁺/Ag.

toLevel4.question: Tin metal is placed into a solution of Fe³⁺(aq). Predict the outcome using ECS data.
toLevel4.correct: A spontaneous reaction occurs: Fe³⁺ is reduced to Fe²⁺ and Sn is oxidised to Sn²⁺
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺ (E° = +0.77 V, higher left) will oxidise Sn (Sn²⁺/Sn E° = −0.14 V, lower right). E°cell = +0.77 − (−0.14) = +0.91 V (positive).

distractors.answer: No reaction occurs because Fe³⁺ and Sn are on the same side of the ECS
distractors.explanation: Fe³⁺ is on the left (oxidised form) and Sn is on the right (reduced form). They are on opposite sides.

distractors.answer: A spontaneous reaction occurs: Sn is reduced to Sn²⁻ and Fe³⁺ is oxidised to Fe⁴⁺
distractors.explanation: Sn is oxidised (loses electrons), not reduced. Fe³⁺ is reduced to Fe²⁺, not oxidised to Fe⁴⁺.

distractors.answer: No reaction occurs because iron has a higher atomic number than tin
distractors.explanation: Atomic number is irrelevant to redox spontaneity. E° values determine which reactions are spontaneous.

toLevel4.question: Will H₂(g) spontaneously reduce Cu²⁺(aq) to Cu(s)? Use the ECS to predict.
toLevel4.correct: Yes; Cu²⁺/Cu (E° = +0.34 V) is higher than H⁺/H₂ (E° = 0.00 V), so Cu²⁺ will oxidise H₂
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Cu²⁺ (E° = +0.34 V, higher left) can oxidise H₂ (E° = 0.00 V, lower right). E°cell = +0.34 − 0.00 = +0.34 V (positive). H₂ reduces Cu²⁺.

distractors.answer: No; H₂ has E° = 0.00 V which means it cannot react with any species at all
distractors.explanation: E° = 0.00 V is the reference point, not zero reactivity. H₂ can reduce species above it on the ECS.

distractors.answer: No; gases cannot participate in redox reactions with metal ions in aqueous solution
distractors.explanation: Gases like H₂ readily participate in redox reactions. This is the basis of the standard hydrogen electrode.

distractors.answer: Yes; but only because Cu²⁺ has a positive E° value, and all positive species react with H₂
distractors.explanation: Not all positive E° species are predicted by this reasoning alone. The spontaneity depends on relative ECS positions.

toLevel4.question: A student wants to dissolve silver metal. Which of these solutions could spontaneously oxidise Ag to Ag⁺?
toLevel4.correct: Cl₂(aq), because Cl₂/Cl⁻ (E° = +1.36 V) is higher than Ag⁺/Ag (E° = +0.80 V)
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Cl₂ (E° = +1.36 V) is higher on the ECS than Ag⁺ (E° = +0.80 V), so Cl₂ can spontaneously oxidise Ag.

distractors.answer: Cu²⁺(aq), because Cu²⁺/Cu (E° = +0.34 V) is a strong enough oxidising agent
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ (E° = +0.34 V) is lower than Ag⁺ (E° = +0.80 V) and cannot oxidise Ag.

distractors.answer: Fe²⁺(aq), because Fe²⁺/Fe (E° = −0.44 V) readily dissolves noble metals
distractors.explanation: Fe²⁺ is actually the reduced form of the Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺ couple. Fe²⁺/Fe has E° = −0.44 V, far below Ag⁺/Ag.

distractors.answer: Zn²⁺(aq), because Zn²⁺/Zn (E° = −0.76 V) has high reactivity with all metals
distractors.explanation: Zn²⁺ (E° = −0.76 V) is much lower than Ag⁺ (E° = +0.80 V) and cannot oxidise Ag.

toLevel4.prompt: Predict the reaction between Mg(s) and Pb²⁺(aq).
toLevel4.sentence: Pb²⁺ (E° = −0.13 V) is higher on the left than Mg²⁺ (E° = −2.37 V). E°cell = −0.13 − ({{blank:1}}) = +{{blank:2}} V, so the reaction is spontaneous.

1.correctExplanation: Mg²⁺/Mg has E° = −2.37 V. As the anode (lower E°), this value is subtracted in the E°cell calculation.

distractors.explanation: Mg²⁺/Mg has E° = −2.37 V (negative), not +2.37 V.
−0.13 V is the E° for Pb²⁺/Pb (cathode). The anode E° is −2.37 V for Mg²⁺/Mg.

toLevel4.prompt: Determine whether a reaction occurs between Cu²⁺(aq) and Ag(s).
toLevel4.sentence: Cu²⁺/Cu (E° = +0.34 V) is {{blank:1}} than Ag⁺/Ag (E° = +0.80 V), so Cu²⁺ {{blank:2}} oxidise Ag.

1.correctExplanation: Cu²⁺/Cu (+0.34 V) has a lower E° than Ag⁺/Ag (+0.80 V), placing it lower on the ECS.

distractors.answer: higher
distractors.explanation: +0.34 V is less positive than +0.80 V. Cu²⁺ is lower on the ECS, not higher.

distractors.answer: equal to
distractors.explanation: +0.34 V and +0.80 V are clearly different. Cu²⁺ is lower.

2.correctExplanation: The oxidising agent (Cu²⁺) must be higher than the species it oxidises. Cu²⁺ is lower than Ag⁺/Ag, so it cannot oxidise Ag.

distractors.answer: can
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ is lower on the ECS than Ag⁺. The oxidising agent must be higher for a spontaneous reaction.

distractors.answer: will always
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ cannot oxidise Ag because it is lower on the ECS. Not all oxidising agents react with all metals.

toLevel4.prompt: Calculate E°cell for the reaction between Cl₂(aq) and I⁻(aq).

1.correctExplanation: Cl₂/Cl⁻ (E° = +1.36 V) is the cathode (higher E°, reduced). I₂/I⁻ (E° = +0.54 V) is the anode (oxidised).

distractors.explanation: +0.54 V is E° for I₂/I⁻ (anode). The cathode is Cl₂/Cl⁻ at +1.36 V.
The E° for Cl₂/Cl⁻ is +1.36 V (positive), not negative.

2.correctExplanation: E°cell = +1.36 − (+0.54) = +0.82 V. Positive, confirming the reaction is spontaneous.

distractors.explanation: 1.90 would result from adding (+1.36 + 0.54). E°cell is calculated by subtraction: 1.36 − 0.54 = 0.82.
0.54 is just the anode E°. E°cell = 1.36 − 0.54 = +0.82 V.

toLevel5.question: A student has access to Mg(s), Fe²⁺(aq), Cu(s), and Ag⁺(aq). Identify all spontaneous reaction pairs.
toLevel5.correct: Ag⁺ + Mg, Ag⁺ + Cu (as reducing agents that Ag⁺ can oxidise), and Fe²⁺ + Mg (Fe²⁺ oxidises Mg)
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Ag⁺ (E° = +0.80 V) can oxidise Mg (E° = −2.37 V) and Cu (E° = +0.34 V). Fe²⁺ (E° = −0.44 V) can oxidise Mg (E° = −2.37 V). Cu cannot be oxidised by Fe²⁺ (Fe²⁺ is lower).

distractors.answer: Only Ag⁺ + Mg, because this pair has the largest E° difference of all combinations
distractors.explanation: The largest E° difference does react, but other valid pairs also react. Ag⁺ + Cu and Fe²⁺ + Mg are also spontaneous.

distractors.answer: All possible pairs react spontaneously because metals always react with metal ions
distractors.explanation: Not all pairs react. Fe²⁺ cannot oxidise Cu because Fe²⁺ is lower on the ECS than Cu²⁺.

distractors.answer: No pairs react because the species are from different groups in the periodic table
distractors.explanation: Periodic table groups do not determine redox spontaneity. Multiple pairs react based on ECS positions.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate: 'Adding Cl₂(aq) to a solution containing both Br⁻(aq) and I⁻(aq) will oxidise both halide ions.' Is this correct?
toLevel5.correct: Yes; Cl₂ (E° = +1.36 V) is higher than both Br₂/Br⁻ (E° = +1.09 V) and I₂/I⁻ (E° = +0.54 V)
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Cl₂ is a stronger oxidising agent than both Br₂ and I₂. It will spontaneously oxidise both Br⁻ and I⁻ because it is higher on the ECS.

distractors.answer: Cl₂ will only oxidise I⁻ because the E° difference with Br⁻ is too small for a reaction
distractors.explanation: The E° difference between Cl₂ and Br₂ is +0.27 V, which is sufficient for a spontaneous reaction. Both are oxidised.

distractors.answer: Cl₂ will only oxidise Br⁻ because Br⁻ is closer to Cl⁻ in the periodic table
distractors.explanation: Periodic table position does not determine which halide is oxidised. Both are below Cl₂ on the ECS.

distractors.answer: No; Cl₂ cannot oxidise other halide ions because they are in the same group
distractors.explanation: Being in the same group does not prevent redox reactions. Cl₂ (stronger oxidising agent) readily oxidises Br⁻ and I⁻.

toLevel5.question: A solution contains Fe³⁺(aq), Cu²⁺(aq), and Ag⁺(aq). Zinc metal is added. Predict the order in which ions are reduced.
toLevel5.correct: Ag⁺ first (E° = +0.80 V), then Fe³⁺ to Fe²⁺ (E° = +0.77 V), then Cu²⁺ (E° = +0.34 V)
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The strongest oxidising agent reacts first. Ag⁺ (+0.80 V) is reduced first, then Fe³⁺ to Fe²⁺ (+0.77 V), then Cu²⁺ (+0.34 V). All are above Zn²⁺/Zn (−0.76 V).

distractors.answer: All three ions are reduced simultaneously because Zn is a strong enough reducing agent
distractors.explanation: While Zn can reduce all three, the strongest oxidising agent reacts preferentially first, then the next strongest.

distractors.answer: Cu²⁺ first because copper is the most common metal in the solution by mass
distractors.explanation: Reduction order depends on E° values, not abundance or mass. The highest E° species reacts first.

distractors.answer: Fe³⁺ first because iron has the most positive E° value of the three ions
distractors.explanation: Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺ is +0.77 V. Ag⁺/Ag is +0.80 V, which is higher. Ag⁺ reacts first.

toLevel5.question: A student proposes using Pb²⁺(aq) to oxidise Sn(s) and using Sn²⁺(aq) to oxidise Pb(s). Can both reactions be spontaneous?
toLevel5.correct: No; only Pb²⁺ + Sn is spontaneous because Pb²⁺ (E° = −0.13 V) is higher than Sn²⁺ (E° = −0.14 V)
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Pb²⁺ is slightly higher on the ECS. The forward reaction (Pb²⁺ + Sn) has E°cell = +0.01 V (positive, spontaneous). The reverse (Sn²⁺ + Pb) has E°cell = −0.01 V (non-spontaneous).

distractors.answer: Yes; both reactions are spontaneous because the E° values are nearly identical
distractors.explanation: Both reactions cannot be spontaneous — they are the reverse of each other. Only the forward direction (positive E°cell) is spontaneous.

distractors.answer: Neither reaction is spontaneous because both E° values are negative numbers
distractors.explanation: Negative E° values do not prevent spontaneity. The E°cell (difference) determines spontaneity, not individual signs.

distractors.answer: Yes; both reactions occur because Sn and Pb are adjacent in the periodic table
distractors.explanation: Periodic table position is irrelevant. Only one direction can be spontaneous for any redox pair.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate whether F₂(g) can spontaneously oxidise Au(s) to Au⁺(aq). Use E° data.
toLevel5.correct: Yes; F₂/F⁻ (E° = +2.87 V) is much higher than Au⁺/Au (E° = +1.68 V), so F₂ can oxidise Au
toLevel5.correctExplanation: F₂ is the strongest oxidising agent on the ECS. Even gold, which resists most oxidisers, can be oxidised by F₂. E°cell = +2.87 − 1.68 = +1.19 V.

distractors.answer: No; gold is a noble metal and cannot be oxidised by any chemical species
distractors.explanation: Gold resists most oxidisers, but F₂ (+2.87 V) is above Au⁺ (+1.68 V) and can oxidise gold.

distractors.answer: No; both species have very high positive E° values, so neither can oxidise the other
distractors.explanation: The relative position matters, not the absolute values. F₂ is higher than Au⁺, so F₂ can oxidise Au.

distractors.answer: Yes; but only because fluorine is in the same period as gold in the periodic table
distractors.explanation: F and Au are not in the same period. The reason is the relative E° positions on the ECS.

toLevel5.question: A galvanic cell is proposed using H₂O₂/H₂O (E° = +1.77 V) and MnO₄⁻/Mn²⁺ (E° = +1.51 V). Will the cell operate with H₂O₂ as the cathode?
toLevel5.correct: Yes; H₂O₂/H₂O (E° = +1.77 V) is higher, so H₂O₂ is reduced at the cathode and MnO₄⁻ is not reduced
toLevel5.correctExplanation: H₂O₂ (E° = +1.77 V) is higher than MnO₄⁻ (E° = +1.51 V), so H₂O₂ is reduced at the cathode. The Mn²⁺ side would be oxidised at the anode.

distractors.answer: No; H₂O₂ always acts as an oxidising agent and cannot be at the cathode
distractors.explanation: H₂O₂ can act as either oxidising or reducing agent depending on the partner. With MnO₄⁻, H₂O₂ is the stronger oxidiser.

distractors.answer: No; both are strong oxidising agents so neither can be reduced in a galvanic cell
distractors.explanation: One must be reduced (cathode) and the other's reduced form must be oxidised (anode). The higher E° is reduced.

distractors.answer: Yes; but E°cell would be negative because both values are above +1.00 V
distractors.explanation: E°cell = +1.77 − 1.51 = +0.26 V, which is positive. Both being above +1.00 V does not make E°cell negative.

toLevel5.question: Iron nails are placed in CuSO₄ solution and a brown coating forms. Explain this observation using the ECS.
toLevel5.correct: Cu²⁺ (E° = +0.34 V) spontaneously oxidises Fe (E° = −0.44 V), depositing Cu(s) on the nail
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Cu²⁺ is higher on the left (stronger oxidising agent) than Fe²⁺/Fe. Fe is oxidised to Fe²⁺ while Cu²⁺ is reduced to Cu, which deposits as a brown coating.

distractors.answer: Fe ions from the nail dissolve and form brown FeS precipitate with sulfate ions
distractors.explanation: FeS is not formed from FeSO₄. The brown coating is metallic copper deposited on the iron surface.

distractors.answer: The nail is coated in iron oxide (rust) due to the oxygen dissolved in the CuSO₄ solution
distractors.explanation: The brown coating is copper metal, not rust. Cu²⁺ is reduced to Cu(s) on the iron surface.

distractors.answer: Cu²⁺ is oxidised to Cu³⁺ which forms a brown compound with the iron surface
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ is reduced (gains electrons) to Cu(s), not oxidised. The brown coating is metallic copper.

toLevel5.question: A student needs to selectively reduce only Ag⁺ from a solution containing Ag⁺(aq) and Cu²⁺(aq) using a metal. Which metal should they choose?
toLevel5.correct: Cu(s), because Cu can reduce Ag⁺ but cannot reduce Cu²⁺ (which is its own ion)
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Cu (E° = +0.34 V) is below Ag⁺ (+0.80 V) so Cu will reduce Ag⁺. Cu cannot reduce Cu²⁺ because that would require Cu to oxidise itself. This selectively removes only Ag⁺.

distractors.answer: Zn(s), because Zn is the most reactive common metal and will reduce everything
distractors.explanation: Zn (E° = −0.76 V) would reduce both Ag⁺ and Cu²⁺, which is not selective.

distractors.answer: Mg(s), because Mg is selective for silver ions due to its high E° value
distractors.explanation: Mg (E° = −2.37 V) would reduce both Ag⁺ and Cu²⁺, not selectively.

distractors.answer: Au(s), because gold only reacts with silver ions and ignores copper ions
distractors.explanation: Au (E° = +1.68 V) is above both Ag⁺ and Cu²⁺ and would not reduce either.

toLevel5.sentence: When Zn is added to a solution of Ag⁺ and Cu²⁺, the ion reduced first is {{blank:1}} because it has the {{blank:2}} E° value.

1.correctExplanation: Ag⁺ (E° = +0.80 V) is the strongest oxidising agent in the solution, so it reacts first with Zn.

distractors.answer: Cu²⁺
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ (E° = +0.34 V) is a weaker oxidising agent than Ag⁺ (+0.80 V). The strongest oxidising agent reacts first.

distractors.answer: Zn²⁺
distractors.explanation: Zn²⁺ is not being reduced; Zn metal is being oxidised. The ions that are reduced are Ag⁺ and Cu²⁺.

2.correctExplanation: The highest E° value indicates the strongest oxidising agent, which has the greatest tendency to accept electrons and react first.

distractors.answer: lowest
distractors.explanation: The lowest E° reacts last, not first. The highest E° species is the strongest oxidising agent and reacts first.

distractors.answer: most negative
distractors.explanation: The most negative E° indicates the weakest oxidising agent. The highest (most positive) E° reacts first.

toLevel5.prompt: Evaluate whether Br₂ can oxidise Cl⁻.
toLevel5.sentence: Br₂/Br⁻ (E° = +1.09 V) is {{blank:1}} than Cl₂/Cl⁻ (E° = +1.36 V) on the ECS, so Br₂ {{blank:2}} spontaneously oxidise Cl⁻.

1.correctExplanation: Br₂/Br⁻ (+1.09 V) is lower on the ECS than Cl₂/Cl⁻ (+1.36 V).

distractors.answer: higher
distractors.explanation: +1.09 V is less positive than +1.36 V, so Br₂ is lower on the ECS, not higher.

distractors.answer: equal to
distractors.explanation: +1.09 V and +1.36 V are clearly different values. Br₂ is lower.

2.correctExplanation: The oxidising agent must be higher on the ECS to spontaneously oxidise the other species. Since Br₂ is lower than Cl₂, it cannot oxidise Cl⁻.

distractors.answer: can
distractors.explanation: Br₂ is below Cl₂ on the ECS. To oxidise Cl⁻, the oxidising agent must be above Cl₂, not below.

distractors.answer: will always
distractors.explanation: Br₂ cannot oxidise Cl⁻. The reverse is true: Cl₂ can oxidise Br⁻.
